[tye ], [localtime://2007-12-12 16:24:00]

Um, no, clicking [Seekers of Perl Wisdom] does not document the section well. It takes you to the section which doesn't tell much about the important stuff that a new visitor needs to know about that section (and being taken to the section means one is likely to be distracted by the section contents and not pay proper attention to the descriptive heading text). None of the points I mentioned are addressed by jumping to the section itself.

There was no faqlet on SoPW, the section, so my documentation was not redundant. And it was purpose-driven. I looked for SoPW and PMD documentation before I created them to decide how to integrate with what existed. What I found were purpose-driven documentation that including some mention of SoPW along with other sections (and not even much of that) and brief descriptions at the top of each section that linked to no documentation. So if you've got too much documentation on SoPW (the section, not the abbr), then it certainly wasn't anywhere that I found it easy to find.

If you want to get rid of redundant information (often an admirable goal but can often be taken too far when purpose-driven documentation is often more appropriate), then you probably first need to create the "one place" that documentation is supposed to live, then you move/merge stuff to there rather than just delete stuff.

But the point of my SoPW and PMD faqlets was not to document those sections. It was to very briefly introduce them and provide links to the more extensive documentation related to them. Of course, there wasn't much SoPW nor PMD documentation that I found to link to anyway. So the faqlets served a useful purpose as real faqlets anyway, such as would be appropriate to link to from those sections. We didn't have anything like them.

But your plan to make every abbreviation link to a rather insultingly short expansion conflicts with much of my goal for those faqlets. I've somewhat repurposed my faqlets and restored them to some (reduced) usefulness for now in a way that I hope doesn't conflict with your plans for "powerful" abbreviation documentation. The abbr.s don't even link back to the abbr. list.

You might want to update the sitedoclets for the sections to link to your "too much" documentation on the sections. And, no, I don't think including in-line all of the documentation on a section at the top of the section would be a good plan, personally, in case you are considering that as the "one place". Though with the tiny amount of documentation I actually found, it might work out well so far. I hope that we'll have more documentation such that just stuffing it at top of the section would be "too much" and I like having a documentation page about the section so you can link to that separately from linking to the section.

Perhaps you can factor out the "basic section descriptions" so they can be used in more than one purpose-driven place. I'm not sure how well that would work with word-smithing documentation so that it flows nicely, however.

You may have noticed a change in the [PerlMonks FAQ]. For a long time I've been uncomfortable with the "Getting Started" section, particularly how it seemed to contain some articles which aren't quite appropriate for absolute beginners. At the same time, the "About" section had some articles which are beginner level, as well as some which aren't really "about" PerlMonks.

So I created a new section (rather, faqlist) called "Advanced PerlMonks Topics", and did a bunch of shuffling. The goal is that "Getting Started" is a place we can point all newbies, either those who have just discovered PerlMonks or those who have just registered as users. "About" should only talk about PerlMonks at a meta- or administrative level; and "Advanced Topics" is for the remaining misc. nodes which only someone who has gotten a feel for the place would appreciate but which don't fit into any of the other more specialized lists. Now feel free to fine-tune! ([shmem], how's that [id://243875|CSS] documentation coming along?)

I'd like to announce a major groundshift here at PerlMonks: via a deft yet subtle renaming, [PerlMonks FAQ] now goes to [483072], the new faqlist-based structure that [demerphq] kindly set up for us. The old top-level FAQ faqlet, [237040], has been retired for the purpose. It is now a PerlMonks FAQ meta-faqlet, i.e. it talks about the PerlMonks FAQ.

Now that we have an easily maintained hierarchy, we should take advantage of it. The FAQ could use some "depth"; currently it's quite flat. To start with, there are some FAQ sections which answer multiple questions all in one page. Not only does this impede indexing the FAQ down to the level of the question, but it means people (including us) have to use internal document anchors to link to questions.

The most blatant example of this is [id://238736], as it's at the top level of the FAQ, but there are others. Each should be broken into multiple separate faqlets (one per question) and subsequently bound together under a faqlist in place of the original single faqlet. Once that's done, the Monk Help nodes need to be searched for occurrences of [238736]# (and such like), and those replaced with links to the corresponding new faqlets. (Update: done.)

Thanks, everyone, for your help!

Ok, Ive added a facility for you to add aribitrary text to a [faqlist]. It works by creating a [faqstring] which is then put into the group. Try to keep these to a minimum. The way you can create one is by prepending '<< ' to the text in the group editor. Once a faqstring is created you can edit it and move it around the list as you choose (well, faqstrings are like CB messages, they can only be 255 chars long). Thus if you want to do an offsite link you could do something like:

<< [href://ultraedit.com|Ultraedit] -- good quality and cheap Win32 Perl editor. offsite

And that line would show up when a faqlist is rendered. Also you can use the setting fields at the bottom to control recursion of the list. If there is no entry faqlist by default recurse when rendered. If there is an entry then only when its value is true will recursion occur. The edit page for [faqlists] could do with some simplification, and we could also use the setting stuff for controlling style and things like that, for instance it might be nice to say that the list should be laid out in a certain column arrangement, or whatever. Feel free to suggest ideas.

Ive put together a proposal for extending the sitedocumentation. The basic idea revolves around using a new faq related type called a faqlist which would be used for organizing documents into a DB level heirarchy. The general nodetypes that would be involved would be:

faqlist
A document and nodegroup. The document part describes the purpose/content of the list.
sitefaqlet
A published SiteDocClan maintained document.
sitedoclet
A published SiteDocClan maintained document used by superdocs
superdoc
Used for documentation that needs to be "smart"
alphafaqlet
A faqlet in preparation

A faqlist is presented as a two part view, the top a description, the bottom a nested tree of links. The rules for how this tree are built are as follows:

The content of the faqlist is built as a nested <ul>, with faqlist nodes being treated as sub lists and recursed into, all other nodetypes are shown by name, with the exception of alphafaqlet's which are only displayed to members of SDC.

Faqlists should be editable by SDC, with the nodegroup list being editable using normal nodegroup (not usergroup!) editing tools.

Likewise faqlists should be creatable by SDC.

Overall this would be fairly simple to do, faqlist becomes a subclass of nodegroup and document, and requires the most work, that of creating a custom display and edit interface. alphafaqlet becomes a simple subclass of sitefaqlet with an overloaded display/edit interface to allow it to be reblessed into a sitefaqlet. I think thats it.

Does this sound good to folks?
